Provision.Text: The Public Service Staffing Tribunal, pursuant to section 109 of the Public Service Employment Acta, hereby makes the annexed Public Service Staffing Tribunal Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Public Service Employment Act.
intervenor means anyone who is allowed under subsection 19(4) to intervene in the hearing of a complaint.
party means anyone who has a right to be heard under subsection 65(3), section 75, subsection 79(1) or section 85 of the Act.

writing includes, with respect to a person with a disability that affects the capacity to communicate in writing, any means of communication that can be used and understood by that person and that may be retained.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of these Regulations, the Canadian Human Rights Commission is a participant in a proceeding in relation to a complaint if the Canadian Human Rights Commission has given notice under subsection 20(3) that it intends to make submissions regarding an issue raised by the complainant involving the interpretation or the application of the Canadian Human Rights Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: References to “the deputy head or the Commission”
Subsection.Text: In these Regulations, a reference to “the deputy head or the Commission”, in the context of a complaint, means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the deputy head, in any case where the complaint relates to a lay-off, revocation, appointment or proposed appointment in respect of which the Commission has authorized the deputy head under section 15 of the Act to exercise or perform any of the Commission’s powers and functions; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Commission, in any other case.

Section.Text: These Regulations apply to all complaints made to the Board under subsection 65(1) or section 74, subsection 77(1) or section 83 of the Act.
A notice that is sent to a party, an intervenor or the Canadian Human Rights Commission is considered to have been received by the party, the intervenor or the Canadian Human Rights Commission on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the notice is sent by electronic means such as electronic mail or fax transmission, the day on which it is sent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the notice is sent by courier or delivered by hand, the day on which it is received; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the notice is sent by mail, the day that is six days after

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of the postmark or the date of the postage meter impression authorized by the Canada Post Corporation, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if both the postmark and the postage meter impression appear on the envelope, the later of them.

Section.MarginalNote: Alternate methods of providing notices and other documents
Section.Text: Despite any provisions of these Regulations, the Board may, in the interest of fairness, establish alternate methods of providing notices and other documents.

Subsection.Text: A party may request the Board to extend or reduce the time within which a complaint may be made or within which notices and other documents must be given in relation to a complaint.
Before determining whether to extend or reduce the time, the Board must provide the other parties an opportunity to make submissions respecting the request.
The Board must determine whether it is in the interest of fairness to extend or reduce the time and, if it is, the length of the extension or reduction.

Section.Text: A time period calculated under these Regulations that ends on a Saturday or a holiday is extended to end on the next day after that is not a Saturday or a holiday.
To ensure the expeditious resolution of complaints, the Board may direct that proceedings be consolidated and may issue directions in respect of the conduct of the consolidated proceedings.

For the purposes of section 5, subsection 17(4) and sections 19 and 27, the Board may deal with a proceeding as informally and expeditiously as the circumstances and the considerations of fairness permit.
No proceeding is invalid by reason only of a defect in form or a technical irregularity.

Subsection.Text: A complaint must be received by the Board no later than 15 days after

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the complainant receives notice of the lay-off, revocation, appointment or proposed appointment to which the complaint relates; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date specified in the notice, if it is a public notice.

Subsection.Text: A complaint is considered to have been received by the Board on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the complaint is sent by electronic means such as electronic mail or fax transmission, the day on which it is sent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the complaint is sent by courier or delivered by hand, the day on which it is received; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the complaint is sent by mail, the day that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of the postmark or the date of the postage meter impression authorized by the Canada Post Corporation, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if both the postmark and the postage meter impression appear on the envelope, the later of them.

Section.Text: A complaint must be filed with the Board in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and fax number of the complainant, and a mailing address or electronic mail address that can be disclosed to all parties;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the complainant’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number or identifier, if any, of the process to which the complaint relates;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the notice of lay-off, revocation, appointment or proposed appointment to which the complaint relates;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the department or agency, branch or sector involved in the process to which the complaint relates;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a reference to the provision of the Act under which the complaint is made;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a full factual description of the events, circumstances or actions giving rise to the complaint, to the extent known by the complainant;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the signature of the complainant or their authorized representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the complaint.

Section.Text: On receiving the complaint, the Board must acknowledge its receipt and send a copy of it and all supporting documents to the deputy head or the Commission.

Within 10 days after receiving a copy of the complaint and all supporting documents, the deputy head or the Commission must provide the Board with the names and business addresses of the other parties, including their electronic mail addresses, if any.
On receiving the names and addresses of the other parties, the Board must send a copy of the complaint and all supporting documents to each of the other parties.

Subsection.Text: The Board must schedule mediation for a complaint unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the complainant informs the Board, no later than 25 days after the date of the letter by which the Board acknowledges receipt of the complaint, that the complainant does not wish to participate in mediation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the deputy head or the Commission informs the Board, no later than 25 days after the deputy head or the Commission receives a copy of the complaint, that they do not wish to participate in mediation.

Subsection.Text: The complainant, the deputy head or the Commission may, with the agreement of the other party, request mediation of the complaint by informing the Board of that request before the date of the hearing.

In the interest of facilitating the resolution of the complaint, the complainant and the deputy head or the Commission must, as soon as possible after the complaint has been filed, exchange all relevant information regarding the complaint.
The exchange of information must be completed no later than 25 days after the date of the letter by which the Board acknowledges receipt of the complaint.

If the complainant, the deputy head or the Commission does not complete the exchange of all relevant information as required by subsections (1) and (2), the Board may order the parties to complete the exchange of all relevant information within the time specified by the Board.

Section.MarginalNote: Request for order to provide information

Subsection.Text: If a party refuses to provide information, the complainant, the deputy head or the Commission may, after the time provided for the exchange of information, request the Board to order that the information be provided.
The request for an order to provide information must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the party making the request;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint to which the request relates;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a list specifying the documents or information requested;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed explanation as to why each requested item is relevant to the complaint; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the request.

Subsection.Text: Any time that is specified in these Regulations in relation to a complaint, notice or document is suspended until the Board renders a decision respecting the request for an order to provide information.

The Board must order that the complainant, the deputy head or the Commission be provided with the information if the Board determines that the information may be relevant and that its provision will not

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: threaten national security;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: threaten any person’s safety; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: affect the validity or continued use of a standardized test, or any part of such a test, or distort the results of a standardized test by giving an unfair advantage to any individual.

Subsection.Text: The Board may make the order to provide information subject to any conditions that it determines are necessary, including any conditions that are necessary to prevent any of the risks referred to in paragraphs (4)(a) to (c).
The conditions apply before and after the hearing or after any other resolution or disposition of the complaint.

Section.Text: Any information obtained under sections 16 and 17 may be used only for purposes of the complaint.

Subsection.Text: Anyone with a substantial interest in a proceeding before the Board may apply to the Board for permission to intervene in the proceeding.
The application must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the applicant’s name, address, telephone number and fax number, and a mailing address or electronic mail address that is to be used for sending documents to the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the applicant’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint that is the subject of the application;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the grounds for intervention and the interest of the applicant in the matter;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the contribution that the applicant expects to make if allowed to intervene;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the signature of the applicant or their authorized representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the application.

Subsection.Text: The Board must give the parties and the Canadian Human Rights Commission, if it is a participant, the opportunity to make representations in respect of the application.
The Board may allow the applicant to intervene after considering the following factors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the applicant is directly affected by the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether the applicant’s position is already represented in the proceeding;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the public interest or the interests of justice would be served by allowing the applicant to intervene; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: whether the input of the applicant would assist the Board in deciding the matter.

Subsection.Text: In allowing the application, the Board may issue directions regarding the role of the intervenor, including any matter relating to the procedure to be followed by the intervenor.

Heading.TitleText: Notice to the Canadian Human Rights Commission

Subsection.Text: If the complainant raises an issue involving the interpretation or application of the Canadian Human Rights Act in a complaint made under subsection 65(1) or 77(1) of the Act, the complainant must give notice to the Canadian Human Rights Commission under subsection 65(5) or section 78 of the Act. The notice must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the complainant’s name, telephone number and fax number, and a mailing address or electronic mail address that can be disclosed to all parties;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the complainant’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the issue involving the interpretation or the application of the Canadian Human Rights Act and of the alleged discriminatory practice or policy;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the prohibited ground of discrimination involved;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the corrective action sought;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the signature of the complainant or the complainant’s authorized representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the notice.

Subsection.Text: The complainant must give a copy of the notice to each of the other parties, to the Board and to each of the intervenors, if any. Those copies do not need to include copies of the complaint.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Notice of intention to make submissions
Subsection.Text: The Canadian Human Rights Commission must, no later than 15 days after receiving the notice, notify the Board whether or not it intends to make submissions regarding the issue referred to in paragraph (1)(d).
The Board must provide a copy of the notice from the Canadian Human Rights Commission to each of the parties and each of the intervenors, if any.

Heading.TitleText: Time Period for Raising Timeliness Objection

Subsection.Text: If the deputy head or the Commission or a person appointed or proposed for appointment wishes to object that the complaint was not made within the period required by section 10, they must do so before the end of the period for exchanging information.
The objection must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the objecting party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the objecting party’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the facts and any documents on which the objecting party relies in making the objection; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the objection.

Subsection.Text: The complainant must provide his or her allegations to each of the other parties, to the Board, to each of the intervenors, if any, and to the Canadian Human Rights Commission, if it is a participant, no later than 10 days after the end of the period for exchanging information.
The allegations must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the complainant’s name, telephone number and fax number, and a mailing address or electronic mail address that can be disclosed to all parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the complainant’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed description of the allegations on which the complainant intends to rely and full particulars of the relevant facts; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the document.

Subsection.Text: If the complainant fails to provide allegations, the Board may dismiss the complaint.
The Board must, on request, permit the complainant to amend an allegation or provide a new allegation if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amendment or new allegation results from information obtained that could not reasonably have been obtained before the complainant submitted his or her original allegations; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is otherwise in the interest of fairness to do so.

Subsection.Text: The request must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, telephone number and fax number of the complainant, and a mailing address or electronic mail address that can be disclosed to all parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the complainant’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a detailed explanation as to why the complainant did not include the allegation with his or her original allegations or as to why the complainant needs to amend his or her allegations, as the case may be;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the new or amended allegation; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the request.

Heading.TitleText: Reply from the Deputy Head or the Commission

Subsection.Text: The deputy head or the Commission, as respondent, must provide its reply to each of the other parties, to the Board, to each of the intervenors, if any, and to the Canadian Human Rights Commission, if it is a participant, no later than 15 days after receiving the complainant’s allegations or amended allegations.
The reply must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the respondent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the respondent’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a full response to any allegations or issues raised in the complaint and full particulars of any additional relevant facts on which the respondent intends to rely; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the reply.

Subsection.Text: If another party wishes to participate in the hearing, he or she must provide his or her reply to the complainant, to the deputy head or the Commission, to the Board, to the other parties, to each of the intervenors, if any, and to the Canadian Human Rights Commission, if it is a participant, no later than 10 days after receiving the reply of the deputy head or the Commission.
The reply must be in writing and must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the party’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a full response to any allegations or issues raised in the complaint and full particulars of any additional relevant facts on which the party intends to rely; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the reply.

Subsection.Text: If a complainant wishes to withdraw his or her complaint, the complainant must file a written notice of the withdrawal with the Board.
The notice of withdrawal must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the complainant’s name, telephone number and fax number, and a mailing address or electronic mail address that can be disclosed to all parties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address, telephone number, fax number and electronic mail address of the complainant’s authorized representative, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Board’s file number for the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that the complainant wishes to withdraw the complaint;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the signature of the complainant or the complainant’s authorized representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the withdrawal.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Notice to other parties and intervenors
Subsection.Text: On receiving the notice of withdrawal, the Board must give notice to each of the other parties, to each of the intervenors, if any, and to the Canadian Human Rights Commission, if it is a participant, that the complaint has been withdrawn and the file has been closed.

Section.Text: The Board is master of the proceedings and may determine the manner and order of the presentation of evidence and arguments at the hearing.

Subsection.Text: The Board must give notice of the date, time and place of the hearing to each of the parties, to each of the intervenors, if any, and to the Canadian Human Rights Commission, if it is a participant.
Unless the matter is urgent, the notice must be given at least seven days before the date of the hearing.

Section.Text: If a party, an intervenor or the Canadian Human Rights Commission, if it is a participant, does not appear at the hearing of a complaint or at any continuance of the hearing and the Board is satisfied that notice of the hearing was sent to that party, intervenor or participant, the Board may proceed with the hearing and dispose of the complaint without further notice.
The Board may adjourn a hearing and must advise of the day, time, place and terms of its continuance.
These Regulations come into force on the later of the day on which they are registered and December 31, 2005.
